repnme.cdata!:
Somalia - Rapid Response Rehabilitation of
            Rural Livelihoods Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rapid Response
            Rehabilitation of Rural Livelihoods Project for Somalia were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            highly satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in an unstable
            setting such as in Somalia, where normal trading is
            disrupted, it is important to base emergency recovery and
            rehabilitation programs on the production of traditional
            crops. These crops substituted for imported foods in the
            local markets thus reducing the impact of soaring global
            food prices on consumers. There is much to be gained by
            designing project activities that build upon ongoing
            programs, as this allows the utilization of knowledge
            accumulated over time by staff of different organizations,
            local communities and the private sector. This, in turn,
            leads to expeditious planning and implementation of project
            activities, especially of repeater programs; reduced costs
            of planning; and smooth implementation of activities due to
            well established relationships with the local authorities,
            communities and project beneficiaries. Involving the
            communities in the identification of target beneficiaries
            (e.g. resource-poor farmers and women headed households) has
            enabled the project to assist the intended and deserving people.

14910834.trustfund:
TF092796-RAPID RESPONSE REHABILITATION
            OF RURAL LIVELIHOODS PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Somalia - Rapid Response Rehabilitation of
            Rural Livelihoods Project : environment and social
            management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rapid Response
            Rehabilitation of Rural Livelihoods Project is to address
            the food crisis in Somalia by removing the production
            constraints and improve food security, rural incomes, and
            community assets. Negative impacts include: terrestrial
            habitat alteration; aquatic habitat disruption; soil
            degradation; land acquisition/ private assets displacement;
            use of inorganic fertilizers; construction nuisance; and
            increase in solid wastes. Mitigation measures include: 1)
            sites to avoid critical habitat through use of existing
            utility and transport corridors, whenever possible; 2)
            re-vegetation of disturbed areas with native plant species;
            3) sites to avoid critical aquatic habitat such as
            watercourses, wetlands, and riparian areas, whenever
            possible; 4) minimizing clearing and disruption to riparian
            vegetation; 5) assess soil characteristics and either avoid
            or provide drainage for areas prone to water logging; 6)
            provide appropriate technologies for integrated soil
            fertility management; 7) ensure road development is
            coordinated with local land use plans and discuss with
            existing governance structures; 8) aappropriate quality and
            quantity use of fertilizers according to soil capacity; and
            9) provide for proper waste disposal, and water supply and
            sanitation facilities.

repnme.cdata!:
Somalia - Rapid Response Rehabilitation of
            Rural Livelihood Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project document concerns the
            Global Food Crisis Response Program (GFRP), which was
            endorsed by the Board on May 29, 2008, and will be financed
            out of and the Food Price Crisis Response (FPCR) Trust Fund
            (TF) to support a Rapid Response Rehabilitation of Rural
            Livelihoods Project (RRRRLP) in Somalia. The objectives of
            the GFRP are to: (i) reduce the negative impact of high and
            volatile food prices on the lives of the poor in a timely
            way; (ii) support governments in the design of sustainable
            policies that mitigate the adverse impacts of high and more
            volatile food prices on poverty while minimizing the
            creation of long-term market distortions; and (iii) support
            broad-based growth in productivity and market participation
            in agriculture to ensure an adequate and sustainable food
            supply response. The worsening food crisis in Somalia points
            to an urgent need for increased financial support and the
            World Bank can best assist by financing funding gaps in
            existing programs being implemented by international,
            national, and non-governmental institutions. This approach
            would enable rapid implementation and greatest impact.  The
            grant will be made to the Food and Agriculture Organization
            of the United Nations (FAO) as the implementing agency. FAO
            is currently involved in numerous projects in Somalia, and
            has an extensive knowledge of the situation on the ground
            and capacity to coordinate and implement in an efficient and
            effective manner. The will help finance, on an urgent basis
            over 18 months to two years, the costs associated with
            increasing crop and livestock production systems.
